Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of cryogen-free low-temperature scanning-probe spectroscopy system for nanophotonic and nanoelectronic device characterization

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The industrialized world and the United States in particular faces a critical Helium shortage, which threatens a multitude of industrial and medical applications requiring cryogenic cooling. For example, Magnetic Resonance Imagery relies on liquid Helium to cool the high-power magnets needed to create interior body images for clinical analysis and medical intervention. Helium is also indispensable to the U.S. space exploration program and other civilian and military uses. This proposal requests funding to purchase an instrument called attoDRY1100 that allows for carrying out sophisticated optical characterization of nanomaterials and devices at extremely low temperatures and high magnetic fields without the need for liquid Helium. This cryogen-free system completely eliminates the current annual liquid Helium operation costs of about $50,000 at Stevens Institute of Technology, and more importantly, avoids the annual consumption of about 5000 liters of a precious noble gas, thereby contributing to a "greener campus". The equipment will be incorporated into the shared-user Nanophotonics Lab at Stevens where it will serve the needs of a growing user base of over 30 students and staff representing 11 research groups from 5 departments at Stevens. The cryogen-free system will advance several NSF-funded projects that address fundamental questions of the light-matter interaction of nanomaterials at the forefront of current research. These projects also target a broad range of photonic devices that have potential transformative applications, such as in national security and sustainable energy. The broader impacts will come from the fact that the requested instrument will be housed in a central user facility which has a history of successful multidisciplinary training of a broad range of students from high school to postdoctoral researchers addressing forefront research in nanotechnology. The PI's will further expand their outreach activities to currently several hundred high schools students in the framework of the SEED program of the American Chemical Society and the ECOES program at Stevens, that will specifically include hands-on education on various nanotechnology tools, including the attoDRY1100.

This proposal requests funding to purchase the attoDRY1100 cryogen-free cryostat with an integrated CFM-I scanning-probe confocal microscope insert. The cryogen-free system will benefit several NSF-funded projects that address fundamental questions of the light-matter interaction in nanomaterials, which include heterostructures of graphene and transition-metal dichalcogenides, ultra-clean carbon nanotubes, lithium-niobate microcavities, catalytic surfaces for biomass conversion, and solution-processed hybrid inorganic-organic semiconductor thin films. These projects target a broad range of photonic devices, including on-chip photodetectors, all-optical modulators, quantum light sources, thin-film organic solar cells, and Zeno-effect-based switches, which imply transformative applications in national security, sustainable energy, and beyond. The attoDRY1100 instrument offers a wealth of new functionalities and measurement modes highly desirable to the ongoing research projects. These include hyperspectral 2D-mapping of photoluminescence and photocurrent signals, cryogenic photolithography with 10 nm resolution, magneto-luminescence studies of confined excitons, in-situ Raman mapping of surface catalysis, and long-term drift-free quantum-optics studies of single quantum emitters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This instrument award supported the acquisition of the attodry1100 cryogen-free spectroscopy system that supported a regional groups of material scientists and photonic engineers that have been provided with new measurement capabilities that continue to be easily accessibility in a centralized facility in the Nanophotonics Lab at Stevens Institute of Technology. With this instrument a number of studies have been carried out by about 20 researchers from 3 universities in NY/NJ that utilized the equipment and its capabilities to cool samples to 4K and apply magnetic fields up to 9T and study the optical response upon laser excitation. Work over the years has led to 10 high profile journal publications with a combined impact factor of 92. These publications reported scientific advances in semiconductor photonics, on-chip quantum information science, and novel solar cell development in various aspect. As a result, some of the projects that the attodry1100 supported significantly advanced our understanding of fundamental light-matter interaction in quantum materials such as single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), two-dimensional materials based on transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs), monolayer boron nitride (hBN), as well as nanoscale confined metal-halide perovskites.

Some key outcomes are found in breaking several material performance records, including the highest ever reported Purcell-factors in SWCNTs as well as for quantum emitters in TMDCs. Related, for both materials the experiments with the attodry1100 revealed record high quantum efficiencies through deterministic coupling to plasmonic nanocavities and furthermore though advances in material growth techniques.

Another outcome is a novel technique to suppress detrimental spectral diffusion in the exciton emission of quantum emitters in SWCNTs, in TMDCs as well as in hBN. By using high-quality atomic-layer-deposition grown aluminum oxide passivation layers a world record in the low temperature exciton linewidth for SWCNT emission of only 18 micro eV was demonstrated. This finding enables frequency-stable quantum light sources and implies the first generation of indistinguishable single photons from a SWCNT. This important finding will have an impact on future quantum photonic technologies since the field has now the ability to address advanced quantum information processing techniques that require such indistinguishable photons, which was previously not possible with this materials platform.

In addition, techniques have been developed to grow perovskites under nanoconfinement with the results that the widespread problem of material degradation in this system has been largely eliminated. While degradation previously has set in after a few days, rendering perovskites useless and preventing their implementation in any commercial technology, the nanoconfined material showed no signs of degradation even after 600 days. This key outcome of the studies on perovskites that were enabled by the attodry1100 have a significant impact on the field of ultra-efficient solar cells that can now be fabricated with year-long stability.

Another important outcome is found in our recent work in Nature Nanotechnology that demonstrated for the first time that deterministic coupling of strain-induced quantum emitters to plasmonic nanocavity modes is possible in 2D monolayers. As a result, arrays with up to 60 cavity-enhanced quantum light sources were demonstrated. Scalability of quantum hardware is one of the most sought-after goals to enable practical on-chip quantum information processing.

Broader Impacts: The demonstrated record-high quantum efficiencies for SWCNTs and TMDC-based quantum emitter enable an efficiency and performance boost for nanoscale light sources, specifically for quantum light sources that are required to realize quantum communication platforms as well as on-chip devices for quantum computing. The demonstrated advances in on-chip scalability of quantum hardware can enable complex geometries required to boost quantum information processing technologies. In this way, the scientific findings directly impacted the NSF defined big ideas. Furthermore, the attodry1100 has positively impacted the environment: This so-called cryogen-free system completely eliminated the previous annual liquid Helium operation costs of about $50,000 at Stevens Institute of Technology, and more importantly, avoids the annual consumption of about 5000 liters of a precious noble gas, thereby contributing to a greener campus, which can be considered as a direct benefit for the general public.

More than 20 students/researchers have received hands-on training on advanced infrastructure to characterize nanomaterials and have thus gained knowledge in STEM related education. The superuser, a graduate student at Stevens, has also provided frequent training and supervision to new users, thereby improving his leadership and team building skills. The program also provided mentoring as well as hands-on experience for 2 undergraduates and 2 high school students from economically disadvantaged backgrounds over summers, thereby expanding their education and career outlook. The PIs have also been actively involved with outreach to children with disabilities through the non-profit organization, Center for All Abilities and have also participated in several Women in Engineering events at local middle schools and at Stevens to engage young female students in STEM-related topics.
